Some days before his death, when he was sleeping at another person’s house, where he had an amor, a frightful row was heard at his own house in his usual bedroom. The wife was horror—stricken, and supposing her hus- band might have changed his mind and come home in a great fury, she sent to ascertain what was the case: and the persons sent came back again, asseverat- ing that they could see nobody in that room. Nevertheless the uproar went on, and if the wife’s assertion may be credsted, next morning all the chairs, tables, and seats were found, horrible to be- hold, lying scattered topsy-turvey‚ all about; be- sides which, deep groans were constantly heard all through the night. A messenger was immediately dispatched to Veroneje, to acquaint the Czar that General Lefort had departed this life. In the in- terim, Boyar Golowin had everything sealed up, and had given the keys to the kinsman of the deceased.
